key_points: Since being selected as Joe Biden's running mate, Kamala Harris has been a visible presence at his side for major announcements and briefings.
Harris press secretary Sabrina Singh compares Harris's approach to the vice presidency to Joe Biden's approach with Barack Obama, emphasizing partnership.
Harris faces unique challenges as the first woman of color to hold the office of Vice President.
Experts anticipate Harris will play a significant role in the Biden administration, contrasting with the more background role of Vice President Mike Pence under Trump.
Biden and Harris's relationship is dynamic and will evolve as they address various administrative and national issues.
The incoming administration will tackle immediate crises with a coordinated approach, where Harris might lead efforts such as congressional approval for funding vaccine distribution.
Harris resigned her Senate seat, with Alex Padilla set to replace her, but did not give a farewell speech due to the Senate's schedule.
Harris is expected to focus on urgent needs, potentially taking charge of different areas as needed.
While Harris's liberal stance in the Senate might affect her legislative role, her experience on committees will benefit her in handling national security and foreign policy.
Activists look to Harris to advocate for racial justice, COVID-19 disparities affecting communities of color, and other transformative agendas.
spokespersons: Elaine Kamarck (Director, Center for Effective Public Management at the Brookings Institution)
Aimee Allison (Founder and President, She the People)
Jotaka Eaddy (Founder and CEO, Full Circle Strategies)
